choices.text: An indicator of considerably increased incidence of major malformation of the fetus.
Equally common in newborn of diabetic and no diabetic mothers.

questions.text: The finding of a single umbilical artery on examination of the umbilical cord after delivery is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A- Presence of single umblical artery significant,It is more common in twins and in babies born of women with diabetes, epilepsy, oligohydramnios, hydramnios, preeclampsia and antepartum hemorrhage. It is frequently associated with congenital malformation of the fetus (20–25%). Renal and genital anomalies, Trisomy 18 are common. There is increased chance of abortion, fetal aneuploidy, prematurity, IUGR and increased perinatal mortality Option B- Single umbilical artery is present in about 1–2% of cases, not in 10% newborns Option D it is more common in diabetics .

questions.text: Wavelength of USG used in obstertrics:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Whenever in questions it does not specify TVS or TAS always take it as TAS. A low frequency transducer (typically 2 to 5 MHz) is used, for trans abdominal Usg which allows penetration through the anterior soft tissues. TVUS, performed with a higher frequency transducer (typically 5 to 12 MHz). Since the area of interest is closer to the probe, less penetration is needed. TVUS allows for earlier and more reliable detection of an intrauterine or ectopic pregnancy (abdominal pregnancies are an exception) and is more sensitive for detecting embryonic cardiac activity at very early gestational ages compared with transabdominal US (TAUS). Hence TVS Is preferred for early pregnancy. → Frequency x Penetration X 1/Resolution So in TAUS ; Low frequency proke used as larger depth penetration required ; hence resolution is poor. So deduction of any event related to pregnancy is earlier with TVS but later waith TAS

choices.text: Stomach and umbilical vein, perpendicular to spine

questions.text: During USG, fetal abdominal circumference is measured at the level of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct answer is a. Stomach and umbilical vein, perpendicular to spine. The fetal abdominal circumference is typically measured at the level where the stomach and umbilical vein can be seen, oriented perpendicular to the fetal spine. This is the standard technique in obstetrical ultrasounds to assess fetal growth and development. At this level, the stomach appears as a round or oval shape, and the umbilical vein is visible, making it a reliable reference point for measuring the abdominal circumference. The abdominal circumference (AC) is a critical parameter measured during ultrasound (USG) in pregnancy to assess fetal growth and well-being. 1. Assessment of Fetal Growth • Estimation of Fetal Weight (EFW): AC is a key component of formulas used to estimate fetal weight, such as the Hadlock formula, which also includes head circumference (HC), femur length (FL), and biparietal diameter (BPD). • Growth Monitoring: Serial measurements of AC can help detect growth abnormalities: • Small for Gestational Age (SGA): Reduced AC may indicate intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). • Large for Gestational Age (LGA): Increased AC may indicate macrosomia or gestational diabetes. 2. Indicator of Nutritional Status • AC reflects fetal liver size and subcutaneous fat deposition, making it a marker of fetal nutritional status. • Reduced AC in the third trimester is often linked to conditions like placental insufficiency or maternal malnutrition. 3. Evaluation of Specific Conditions • IUGR: In asymmetric IUGR, the AC is disproportionately smaller compared to the head circumference (HC), indicating “brain-sparing” in the fetus. • Macrosomia: Excessive AC, especially when compared with HC, may indicate fetal macrosomia, commonly seen in pregnancies complicated by gestational diabetes or obesity. 4. Monitoring High-Risk Pregnancies • AC measurements are essential in pregnancies with complications such as: • Maternal hypertension • Diabetes mellitus • Previous history of IUGR or macrosomia • Multiple gestations

questions.text: Fetal anemia is detected on Doppler of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Middle cerebral artery. Fetal anemia is often detected through Doppler ultrasound measurement of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). When the fetus is anemic, there is increased blood flow to the brain in an attempt to compensate for the reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. This results in a higher peak systolic velocity (PSV) in the MCA. This method is widely used as an indirect indicator of fetal anemia, particularly in conditions like Rh incompatibility or fetal blood loss. Option A, uterine artery, is not the correct answer because the uterine artery is primarily assessed for indications of placental insufficiency or preeclampsia risk, not for detecting fetal anemia. The uterine artery Doppler measures blood flow to the placenta, which can be helpful in evaluating maternal-fetal conditions but does not directly indicate fetal anemia. Option B, umbilical artery, is typically used to assess fetal well-being, particularly for detecting fetal hypoxia or growth restriction. While an abnormal umbilical artery Doppler, such as increased resistance, can indicate placental insufficiency, it is not specifically used to detect fetal anemia. The umbilical artery reflects placental blood flow rather than the fetal blood flow to organs such as the brain.

questions.text: Parameter not used to determine fetal age in midtrimester USG:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) CRL (Crown-Rump Length). In mid-trimester ultrasounds, the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) is not typically used to determine fetal age because it is most accurate in the early first trimester. CRL is a measurement of the fetus from the top of the head (crown) to the bottom of the spine (rump), and it is used primarily for dating in the early stages of pregnancy when the embryo is small. By the mid-trimester, other parameters become more reliable for assessing fetal age. Now let's look at the incorrect answers: a. BPD (Biparietal Diameter): The Biparietal Diameter, which measures the width of the fetal head from one side to the other, is a commonly used parameter to assess fetal age during the mid-trimester. This measurement is reliable after the first trimester and can help estimate the gestational age based on fetal head development. b. Femur length: Femur length is another useful measurement in the mid-trimester for determining fetal age. It is an accurate indicator of growth and development during this period, and measurements of the fetal femur are often used to confirm gestational age when combined with other parameters. c. HC (Head Circumference): Head circumference, the measurement around the fetal head, is commonly used during the mid-trimester to estimate fetal age. It is a good indicator of fetal growth and development, particularly in the second trimester, and is widely used in obstetric ultrasound to assess fetal well-being and age.

questions.text: Double bleb signs in USG are depictive of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amniotic sac and yolk sac. The "double bleb sign" in ultrasound refers to the appearance of two separate structures, the amniotic sac and the yolk sac, visible within the developing pregnancy. This sign is seen in early gestation, typically around the 5th to 6th week of pregnancy, and is considered a normal finding. The two sacs are aligned close to each other and are often seen in cross-section, giving the characteristic "double bleb" appearance, which is a positive sign of a viable intrauterine pregnancy. Now let's look at the incorrect answers: a. Intrauterine two gestations sac: This option refers to a twin pregnancy, where there are two separate gestational sacs within the uterus. However, the double bleb sign is not indicative of two separate gestational sacs. It specifically refers to the appearance of a single gestational sac containing the amniotic and yolk sacs, not two separate sacs. c. Ectopic pregnancy: In an ectopic pregnancy, the fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, usually in the fallopian tube, and the double bleb sign is not seen. Ectopic pregnancies may present with different ultrasound findings, such as an empty uterus and a mass or gestational sac outside the uterine cavity, but the double bleb sign is not characteristic of this condition. d. Heterotopic pregnancy: A heterotopic pregnancy occurs when there is both an intrauterine pregnancy and an ectopic pregnancy simultaneously. While this is a rare condition, it would not present with the double bleb sign. The sign is specific to a normal intrauterine pregnancy, and the presence of an ectopic pregnancy would complicate the ultrasound findings, making it unlikely to show this specific sign.

questions.text: Transvaginal USG can detect fetal cardiac activity in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 6 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound is sensitive enough to detect fetal cardiac activity as early as 6 weeks of gestation. At this point, the fetal heart begins to beat, and with the high-resolution images provided by transvaginal ultrasound, the movement of the fetal heart can be clearly visualized. This makes 6 weeks the earliest time that fetal cardiac activity can be reliably detected. ultrasound findings in early pregnancy: 1. 4-5 Weeks: • Gestational sac visible in the uterus (first sign of pregnancy). • Mean sac diameter (MSD) >2-3 mm confirms pregnancy. 2. 5-6 Weeks: • Yolk sac becomes visible inside the gestational sac. • Fetal pole may appear. • Cardiac activity detectable by 5.5-6 weeks (fetal heartbeat >90 bpm). 3. 6-7 Weeks: • Embryo clearly visible; crown-rump length (CRL) can be measured. • Cardiac activity (fetal heartbeat) well-established (>100 bpm). 4. 7-8 Weeks: • Limb buds and head structures become visible. • Accurate dating using CRL. 5. 8-10 Weeks: • Fetal movements observed. • Organs start forming (organogenesis). 6. 10-12 Weeks: • Nuchal translucency (NT) scan can be done to assess chromosomal abnormalities. • Placental development visible.

questions.text: Earliest detection of pregnancy by ultrasound is by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gestation sac. The earliest sign of pregnancy detectable by ultrasound is the gestational sac. The gestational sac can be seen as early as 4 to 5 weeks of gestation using transvaginal ultrasound, even before the fetal pole or heartbeat is visible. The gestational sac is the first structure to appear in the uterus and is a reliable marker of early pregnancy. Its detection marks the initial confirmation of an intrauterine pregnancy. In early pregnancy, ultrasound findings like the gestational sac, intradecidual sign, double decidual sign, and double bleb sign are crucial for confirming an intrauterine pregnancy and assessing its viability. 1. Gestational Sac • Definition: The first structure visible on ultrasound, indicating early intrauterine pregnancy. • Timing: Seen as early as 4.5-5 weeks of gestation. • Appearance: A round or oval hypoechoic structure surrounded by a thick echogenic rim (the decidua). • Location: Within the endometrial cavity, not the adnexa (helps differentiate from ectopic pregnancy). 2. Intradecidual Sign • Definition: The gestational sac is located eccentrically within the thickened decidua of the endometrium. • Timing: Seen at 4.5-5 weeks of gestation. • Significance: Suggests an early intrauterine pregnancy before the yolk sac or embryo is visible. • Appearance: A small fluid collection with an echogenic rim in the thickened decidua. 3. Double Decidual Sign • Definition: Two concentric echogenic rings around the gestational sac, formed by the decidua capsularis (inner ring) and the decidua parietalis (outer ring). • Timing: Seen around 5-6 weeks of gestation. • Significance: Strong indicator of an intrauterine pregnancy (distinguishes from pseudogestational sacs seen in ectopic pregnancies). 4. Double Bleb Sign • Definition: Visualization of two closely positioned structures within the gestational sac: the yolk sac and the amniotic sac. • Timing: Seen at 5.5-6 weeks of gestation. • Appearance: Two small bubbles adjacent to each other (yolk sac and amniotic sac) with the developing embryo located between them. • Significance: Confirms early pregnancy and embryonic development.

questions.text: In transvaginal ultrasound, earliest detection of gestation sac is by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 21 days after ovulation. In transvaginal ultrasound, the earliest detection of the gestational sac typically occurs about 21 days after ovulation. This corresponds to approximately 5 weeks of gestation. At this time, the gestational sac becomes visible on ultrasound, marking the earliest sign of an intrauterine pregnancy. The transvaginal approach provides better resolution and allows for the detection of the gestational sac earlier than abdominal ultrasound. The first sign of pregnancy visible on ultrasound is the gestational sac, a fluid-filled structure in the uterus. It can usually be seen around 4-5 weeks of pregnancy. The yolk sac is a small circular structure within the gestational sac, typically visible around 5-6 weeks of pregnancy. It provides nutrients to the embryo in early pregnancy before the placenta takes over. The embryo usually becomes visible around 5-6 weeks. It appears as a small, rounded shape within the gestational sac. The fetal heart is typically detectable via ultrasound by 6 weeks of gestation. The presence of a heartbeat is a strong indicator of a viable pregnancy. A normal fetal heart rate ranges from 110 to 180 beats per minute. The crown-rump length (CRL) is a key measurement used to estimate fetal age, taken from the top of the head (crown) to the bottom of the buttocks (rump). This measurement is most accurate for dating the pregnancy between 6-9 weeks.

questions.text: A pregnant women who is 7 weeks from her LMP comes in to the office for her first prenatal visit. Her previous pregnancy ended in a missed abortion in the first trimester. The patient therefore is very anxious about the well-being of this pregnancy. Which of the following modalities will allow you to best document fetal heart action?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Transvaginal sonogram. A transvaginal sonogram is the most accurate modality for visualizing fetal heart activity at 7 weeks of gestation. At this early stage, the fetal heartbeat can be detected using a transvaginal ultrasound, which provides high-resolution images and clear visualization of the fetal heart. This method allows for the best assessment of fetal well-being and is ideal for confirming the presence of a heartbeat, especially in a patient with a history of a missed abortion. Now let's look at the incorrect answers: A. Regular stethoscope: A regular stethoscope cannot detect fetal heart tones at 7 weeks of gestation. It is typically used in later stages of pregnancy, around 20 weeks or more, when the fetal heart tones are louder and easier to auscultate. At 7 weeks, the fetal heart is too small and the sounds too faint to be detected by a regular stethoscope. B. Fetoscope: A fetoscope is a specialized stethoscope designed for listening to fetal heart sounds. However, it also is not effective at detecting fetal heart action as early as 7 weeks. Similar to the regular stethoscope, it is usually used in later stages of pregnancy when the fetal heart is larger and more audible, typically after 18-20 weeks. C. Special fetal Doppler equipment: While fetal Doppler equipment can detect fetal heart sounds, it is usually effective after 10-12 weeks of gestation, when the fetal heart is more developed and the sounds become more pronounced. At 7 weeks, a transvaginal ultrasound is the most reliable method to visualize fetal heart action. The Doppler is not sensitive enough at this early stage to provide an accurate reading.

choices.text: Gestational sac can be seen at 2 weeks
Detection of cardiac activity establishes the fetus age to approximately 3 weeks
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound decreases after first trimester
The yolk sac is the first structure that is visible on ultrasound during pregnancy

questions.text: A 26 year old comes to clinic with a positive home pregnancy test. For past 2 days she has nausea and abdominal pain. Ultrasound shows a normal viable fetus at 8 weeks. Which of the following regarding first trimester ultrasound is correct
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound decreases after the first trimester. In the first trimester, ultrasound is highly accurate for determining gestational age, with measurements like crown-rump length (CRL) being particularly reliable. As the pregnancy progresses, the accuracy of ultrasound in estimating gestational age decreases, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to variations in fetal growth rates. By the second trimester, the range of normal for fetal measurements increases, leading to less precise dating of gestational age. Methods for Gestational Age Assessment 1. Last Menstrual Period (LMP): • GA is calculated from the first day of the LMP. • Assumes a regular 28-day cycle with ovulation on day 14. • Can be inaccurate with irregular cycles or uncertain dates. 2. Ultrasound (USG): • Most accurate in the first trimester. Used when LMP is uncertain or differs from early ultrasound findings. Ultrasound Parameters by Trimester 1. First Trimester: • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): • Most accurate method for dating (±5-7 days). • Used from 6-13 weeks of gestation. • Gestational Sac Size: Useful when no embryo is visible (4-5 weeks). 2. Second Trimester: • Biometric Parameters: • Biparietal Diameter (BPD): Measures the width of the fetal head. • Head Circumference (HC): Reflects head size. • Abdominal Circumference (AC): Correlates with fetal growth and weight. • Femur Length (FL): Measures fetal skeletal growth. • Accuracy: ±10-14 days. 3. Third Trimester: • Biometric Parameters: Same as the second trimester. • Less accurate (±21 days) due to variability in fetal growth. Clinical Examination: • Fundal Height: Measured from the pubic symphysis to the uterine fundus. • Rough estimate of GA after 20 weeks (e.g., fundal height ? GA in weeks).

questions.text: A 31-year-old G1P0 presents to your o?ce at 22 weeks gestation for a second opinion. She was told that her baby has a birth defect. She has copies of the ultrasound ?lms and asks you to review them for her. The ultrasound image below shows the birth defect. Which of the following is the most likely defect
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Encephalocele. Encephalocele is a neural tube defect in which brain tissue and meninges protrude through an opening in the skull. This defect is often identified on prenatal ultrasound by the presence of an unusual mass or bulge on the fetus's head. The mass is typically fluid-filled and can contain brain tissue or cerebrospinal fluid. The ultrasound images would likely show this characteristic protrusion, helping to identify encephalocele as the most likely defect in this case. Now let's look at the incorrect answers: A. Cystic hygroma: A cystic hygroma is a fluid-filled sac that typically forms around the neck or head, due to abnormal development of the lymphatic system. It is often detected on ultrasound as a fluid-filled mass, but it would not present as a mass coming from the skull, as seen in encephalocele. Cystic hygromas are generally located in the neck and do not contain brain tissue, distinguishing them from encephalocele. C. Anencephaly: Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect where the brain and skull fail to develop properly, resulting in the absence of most of the brain and the skull. On ultrasound, the absence of a developed brain and skull would be noted. However, encephalocele involves a protrusion of brain tissue through the skull, which is distinct from the absence of the brain tissue seen in anencephaly. Therefore, anencephaly would not present with the bulging mass characteristic of an encephalocele. D. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect where the abdominal organs, such as the intestines or liver, protrude through the abdominal wall, usually covered by a membrane. This defect is located in the abdomen, not the head. It would appear on ultrasound as an abdominal mass, not as a cranial protrusion like that seen in encephalocele. Therefore, it is not consistent with the description of a birth defect involving the head.

questions.text: When is the gestational sac typically visible on transvaginal ultrasound?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 5 weeks The gestational sac is typically visible on transvaginal ultrasound around 5 weeks of pregnancy. At this point, the sac is large enough to be detected, but the embryo itself may not yet be visible. The gestational sac is the earliest structure that can be seen in the uterus, and its appearance on ultrasound is one of the first indicators of a viable pregnancy. By 5 weeks, the gestational sac is generally detectable,

questions.text: At what gestational age can fetal heart activity first be detected on transvaginal ultrasound?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 6 weeks Fetal heart activity can first be detected on transvaginal ultrasound around 6 weeks of gestation. At this point, the embryonic heart begins to beat, and it can be visualized as a flicker on the ultrasound image. While a gestational sac may be seen earlier (around 5 weeks), fetal heart activity is generally not visible until 6 weeks when the heart has developed sufficiently to be detected with ultrasound.

questions.text: A woman with irregular menstrual cycles presents with a positive pregnancy test but no gestational sac on transvaginal ultrasound. What is the next best step
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Repeat ?-hCG in 48 hours In this scenario, the most appropriate next step is to repeat the ?-hCG test in 48 hours. The absence of a gestational sac on transvaginal ultrasound could indicate either an early intrauterine pregnancy that is too early to visualize or a possible ectopic pregnancy. ?-hCG levels should normally double approximately every 48 hours in a normal intrauterine pregnancy. If the ?-hCG level fails to rise appropriately, this suggests a possible ectopic pregnancy, or the pregnancy may not be viable. If the ?-hCG level is rising appropriately, it may be simply too early to see the gestational sac, and further follow-up ultrasounds may be necessary

questions.text: What is the discriminatory zone for β-hCG, above which a gestational sac should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2000-3500 mlU The discriminatory zone for ?-hCG is typically between 2000-3500 mlU, above which a gestational sac should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound. This range is based on studies that correlate the ?-hCG level with the likelihood of being able to visualize a gestational sac on ultrasound. When ?-hCG levels exceed this threshold, it is expected that the gestational sac should be detectable by transvaginal ultrasound, provided the pregnancy is intrauterine. If no sac is seen, this raises concerns about the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy or a very early intrauterine pregnancy

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles and a positive pregnancy test. Ultrasound shows an empty gestational sac without a fetal pole at 7 weeks. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Blighted ovum A blighted ovum, also known as an anembryonic pregnancy, occurs when a gestational sac forms but the embryo does not develop, resulting in an empty sac. In this case, the woman presents with a positive pregnancy test, irregular menstrual cycles, and an ultrasound showing an empty gestational sac at 7 weeks, which is consistent with a blighted ovum. This is a common cause of early pregnancy loss and typically presents as a pregnancy where the gestational sac is present, but no fetal pole or embryo is visible. The lack of a fetal pole at 7 weeks in this case is the key feature supporting this diagnosis.

questions.text: Nuchal translucency (NT) Measurement is typically performed during which gestational period?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 11-14 weeks Nuchal translucency (NT) measurement is typically performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation, which is the optimal time for assessing the thickness of the nuchal fold at the back of the fetal neck. This ultrasound measurement is part of the first-trimester screening for chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21). The nuchal translucency test is used in combination with other biomarkers (like PAPP-A and free beta-hCG) to calculate the risk for Down syndrome. The accuracy of NT measurement is highest within this window, as the translucency becomes less reliable after 14 weeks due to fetal growth and anatomical changes

choices.text: Thickened endometrium with a trilaminar pattern
Gestational sac with a double decidual sign

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with a history of amenorrhea for 6 weeks. Which of the following ultrasound findings is the most reliable indicator of intrauterine pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fetal cardiac activity Fetal cardiac activity is the most reliable and definitive ultrasound finding confirming a viable intrauterine pregnancy (IUP). It is usually detectable by transvaginal ultrasound between 5.5 to 6.0 weeks of gestation and confirms not only the presence of an intrauterine gestation but also viability. The presence of a fetal heartbeat ensures that the gestational sac contains a developing embryo rather than being an anembryonic pregnancy or a pseudogestational sac (as may be seen in ectopic pregnancy). This makes it the gold standard for confirming an IUP.

choices.text: Indicator of increased risk of major malformation
Equally common in newborn of diabetic and non diabetic mothers

questions.text: Finding of single umbilical artery is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Indicator of increased risk of major malformation The finding of a single umbilical artery (SUA), where only one artery is present in the umbilical cord instead of the usual two, is associated with an increased risk of major malformations in the fetus. This can include defects in the cardiovascular, renal, and gastrointestinal systems, as well as chromosomal abnormalities. SUA is found in about 1% of pregnancies, and its presence can be a marker for potential structural abnormalities or congenital defects. It is often detected through ultrasound and may warrant further diagnostic evaluation

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, 20 weeks pregnant, has been told by her doctor that her baby has a developmental abnormality. Seeking a second opinion, she shows you the ultrasound findings. Based on these, identify the defect:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anencephaly Anencephaly is a neural tube defect where there is absence of the forebrain (cerebrum) and the skull. It is characterized by the absence of a major part of the brain and skull that forms early in pregnancy. On ultrasound, anencephaly is seen as the absence of the cranial vault, with only the brainstem being present. This condition is incompatible with life and is typically diagnosed early during the second trimester of pregnancy, around 14–20 weeks.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, G1P0, visits the antenatal clinic for her ultrasound at 10 weeks of gestation and wants to know the estimated age of her fetus. Which parameter is most reliable for accurately estimating is most reliable for accurately estimating fetal age in early pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Crown-rump length (CRL) The crown-rump length (CRL) is the most reliable parameter for estimating fetal age, particularly in early pregnancy (up to about 12 weeks). The CRL measures the length of the fetus from the top of the head (crown) to the bottom of the buttocks (rump). This measurement is highly accurate and has a strong correlation with gestational age in the first trimester, making it the gold standard for estimating fetal age at this stage of pregnancy
